title: Definition of a Bar Graph
text: Bar graphs show different bars that are separated from one another, separating categorical data into their categories. The bars are rectangles that can be horizontal or vertical.

title: Determining the Categories for the Bins
text: Since we're using vertical bars, our horizontal axis will list out the categories. Are the categories the district or the percents? Think about how we're separating the data into different groups. What are those groups?

title: Determining the Horizontal Axis
text: Knowing that the categories are distincts, which graph can we EXCLUDE?

subHints.title: Determining the Horizontal Axis
subHints.text: Which graph does not have district on the horizontal axis?

title: Correctness of Bins
text: From the three remaining graphs, Graph A, C, and D, we can determine next which one does not correspond to any data set from the table.

title: Correctness of Bins
text: Which graph does not use data from the table? Specifically, which table doesn't use either the Registered voter population or Overall city population?

subHints.title: Correctness of Bins
subHints.text: For district $$1$$, which graph of Graph A, C, or D does not have a data point of $$15.5\%$$ or $$19.4\%\%$$?

title: Correctness of Data Values for Each Bin
text: Now we're down to the final two: Graph A and Graph C. To determine which bar graph is correct, we must determine which one uses the correct data points. We know that one graph uses the Registered voter population percentages while the other uses the overall city population percentages.

title: Correctness of Data Values for Each Bin
text: We specifically want the graph of the registered voter population percentages. Which of Graph A or C uses this?

subHints.title: Correctness of Data Values for Each Bin
subHints.text: For district $$1$$, which graph of Graph A or C has a data point of $$15.5\%$$?
